Wireless charging is a way to get power to a battery-powered device like a cell phone without using a wire. There is a small base that is plugged in to the wall. When you set your phone on it, it charges. There are a lot of ways to do that, but the popular term “wireless charging” is usually referring to a Wireless Power Consortium standard called Qi (pronounced “chee”). Here’s a simple analogy for how it works: Imagine you have two magnets, one in your charging base and one in your cell phone. If they’re close enough, turning one magnet will make the other turn. Using a motor turning the base magnet, and a generator to harness power from the phone magnet, the generator can use that power to charge the phone. The motor and generator have just been combined with their magnets to manage the rotating magnetic field in a more efficient way. Qi is primarily built to work like an air-core transformer. Transformers work by using electromagnetic coils to build a magnetic field on the input side, and then similar electromagnetic coils on the receiving side to turn that field back into electricity. This is usually for the purpose of converting voltage, but it can also get power across an air gap. There is one last thing Qi does: the cell phone will briefly put the “brakes” on the rotating magnetic field in a special pattern that tells the base how strong to make the field. This ensures that the base charges the phone at the right rate, and doesn’t heat up loose change or waste power when the phone isn’t there. Here are the internals to a Qi charging base:  The coil produces the rotating magnetic field, and it’s backed by a gray ferrite pad to store, aim and shape the magnetic field ideally. The receiving coil looks very similar, but it’s smaller. This is hidden between the battery and the rear of the case in Qi-enabled phones.
